abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>We report truncating de novo variants in specific exons of <jats:italic>FBRSL1</jats:italic> in three unrelated children with an overlapping syndromic phenotype with respiratory insufficiency, postnatal growth restriction, microcephaly, global developmental delay and other malformations. The function of <jats:italic>FBRSL1</jats:italic> is largely unknown. Interestingly, mutations in the <jats:italic>FBRSL1</jats:italic> paralogue <jats:italic>AUTS2</jats:italic> lead to an intellectual disability syndrome (AUTS2 syndrome). We determined human <jats:italic>FBRSL1</jats:italic> transcripts and describe protein-coding forms by Western blot analysis as well as the cellular localization by immunocytochemistry stainings. All detected mutations affect the two short N-terminal isoforms, which show a ubiquitous expression in fetal tissues. Next, we performed a Fbrsl1 knockdown in <jats:italic>Xenopus laevis</jats:italic> embryos to explore the role of Fbrsl1 during development and detected craniofacial abnormalities and a disturbance in neurite outgrowth. The aberrant phenotype in <jats:italic>Xenopus laevis</jats:italic> embryos could be rescued with a human N-terminal isoform, while the long isoform and the N-terminal isoform containing the mutation p.Gln163* isolated from a patient could not rescue the craniofacial defects caused by Fbrsl1 depletion. Based on these data, we propose that the disruption of the validated N-terminal isoforms of FBRSL1 at critical timepoints during embryogenesis leads to a hitherto undescribed complex neurodevelopmental syndrome.</jats:p>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: Informed consent was obtained from the parents of the patients. The present study was approved by the ethics committee of the faculty of Medicine, University of Göttingen (file no 3/2/16).
